questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with bilateral pneumonia that is caused by an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid

Explanation:

Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid would be the ideal option for this patient.

Extended-spectrum beta-lactamase is an enzyme that provides the bacteria with resistance to most penicillins, cephalosporins and even the monobactam aztreonam except carbapenems which are effective against ESBL-producing bacteria.

Beta-lactamase inhibitors have shown effectiveness against such enzyme-producing bacteria. These drugs should be used appropriately with other penicillins or cephalosporins to act against such beta-lactamase-producing organisms like Klebsiella or Enterococcus.

The table below shows the beta-lactamase inhibitors along with their combinations with penicillins/beta-lactams.

Amoxicillin, ticarcillin

Clavulanic acid

Ampicillin, cefoperazone

Sulbactam

Piperacillin, ceftolozane

Tazobactam

Meropenem

Vaborbactam

Imipenem

Relebactam

Ceftazidime

Avibactam

questions.text: All are true about colistin except?

choices.text: It is primarily used as a last-resort treatment for multidrug-resistant bacterial infections.
It is associated with potential nephrotoxic and neurotoxic side effects.
It is known for its efficacy against gram-negative bacteria.
It is primarily administered via oral route.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is primarily administered via oral route.

Explanation:

Colistin

Type

Polypeptide antibiotic

Pharmacokinetics
  • Administration: IV or via inhalation 
  • Distribution: Poor penetration into tissues, primarily stays in the blood
  • Metabolism: Minimal metabolism
  • Excretion: Primarily excreted unchanged in urine

Mechanism of Action

Colistin ⟶ Binds to Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) in Gram-negative Bacterial Cell Walls ⟶ Disrupts Membrane Integrity ⟶ Increases Permeability of Cell Membrane ⟶ Leakage of Intracellular Contents ⟶ Bacterial Cell Death

Uses
  • Multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacterial infections (Option C)
    • Pseudomonas
    • Acinetobacter
    • Klebsiella pneumoniae
    • Escherichia coli
  • Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
  • Catheter-associated UTI

Side Effects
  • Nephrotoxicity (Option B)
  • Neurotoxicity (paresthesias, dizziness, confusion) (Option B)
  • Respiratory depression (with systemic use)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions (rare)
  • Neuromuscular blockade (rare)
  • Superinfection (especially with prolonged use) (rare)

Special Points
  • Due to its toxicity profile and risk of resistance development, it is considered a last-line option for treating multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections (Option A).
  • Inhalation treats respiratory infections, particularly in cystic fibrosis patients with Pseudomonas aeruginosa colonisation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is admitted to the ICU for ventilator-associated pneumonia. He has been on mechanical ventilation for the past 48 hours due to respiratory failure secondary to severe sepsis. Cultures from his sputum reveal vancomycin-resistant organisms. What would be the preferred drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Linezolid

Explanation:

Linezolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic that has activity against vancomycin-resistant organisms, including Vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE).

It is often considered the preferred choice for infections caused by vancomycin-resistant organisms causing lung infections/ pneumonia.

Linezolid

Type/Class

Oxazolidinone antibiotic

Pharmacokinetics
  • Administration: Oral or IV
  • Absorption: Well-absorbed orally, with bioavailability of approximately 100%
  • Distribution: Widely distributed in body tissues, including the lungs, skin, and bone
  • Metabolism: Minimal metabolism
  • Excretion: Excreted unchanged in urine

Mechanism of Action

Linezolid ⟶ Binds to the 50S Ribosomal Subunit ⟶ Inhibits Initiation of Protein Synthesis ⟶ Blocks Elongation of Peptide Chains ⟶ Inhibits Bacterial Protein Synthesis ⟶ Bacteriostatic or Bactericidal Activity.

Uses
  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
  • Vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA)
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Complicated skin and skin structure infections
  • Nosocomial pneumonia (including those caused by MRSA)

Side Effects
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Rash
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Peripheral neuropathy (with prolonged use)
  • Serotonin syndrome
  • Lactic acidosis (rare)

 

  • Daptomycin is DOC for VRSA in skin infections (Option D)
  • Linezolid is DOC for VRSA in lung infections.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, watery diarrhoea, and fever. She has a history of recent antibiotic use for a respiratory infection. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness and distension. A colonoscopy showed the presence of pseudomembranes. Based on these findings, what is the best treatment choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vancomycin

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of a patient with severe abdominal pain, watery diarrhoea, fever with a history of recent antibiotic use, and colonoscopy showing pseudomembranes is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis. Among the given options, vancomycin is the best drug to manage this condition.

Pseudomembranous enterocolitis:

  • Cause: Clostridium difficle & antibiotics.
    • Clindamycin.
    • 3rd generation cephalosporins.
    • Ampicillin.
    • Fluoroquinolones.
  • The antibiotics kill the gut flora, leading to Clostridium difficle superinfection.
  • Management:
    • Fidaxomicin.
    • Vancomycin.
    • Metronidazole.

(Option A and D ruled out)

  • For an initial episode of pseudomembranous colitis, fidaxomicin is preferred due to its safety profile and higher beneficial effects.
    • In resource-limited settings where fidaxomicin is unavailable, vancomycin can be used. (Option C)
  • Metronidazole was previously used as a first-line treatment for pseudomembranous colitis; however, it is no longer the preferred treatment due to increasing resistance and higher recurrence rates than vancomycin. (Option B)

Other uses of vancomycin:

  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Vancomycin is not effective against PSEUDOMONAS

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of Staphylococcus aureus infection is being treated with antibiotics. During his treatment, he develops a sudden onset of flushing, redness of the upper body, and pruritus (itching). Which drugs are most likely responsible for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Vancomycin

Explanation:

  • Red Man Syndrome is a well-known adverse reaction to vancomycin.
  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic with the potential to release histamine by direct action on mast cells through rapid intravenous injection, causing chills, fever, urticaria, and intense flushing, known as Red man syndrome.
  • It can be ameliorated by administering vancomycin more slowly, sometimes with premedication with histamine blockers. Red man syndrome is not observed with teicoplanin.
  • Other side effects of vancomycin:

Common

Rare
  • Nephrotoxicity (especially with prolonged use or high doses).
  • Ototoxicity (especially with rapid infusion or high doses).
  • Thrombophlebitis at IV site.
  • Neutropenia.
  • Anaphylaxis.

questions.text: All are true regarding aztreonam except?

choices.text: Used primarily to treat Gram-negative bacterial infections.
It can be administered both orally and intravenously.
It has a low cross-reactivity with penicillins, making it suitable for patients with penicillin allergies.
Primarily undergoes renal excretion and requires dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) It can be administered both orally and intravenously.

Explanation:

Aztreonam is administered intravenously (IV) or intramuscularly (IM), not orally.

Aztreonam

Type

Monobactam Antibiotic

Pharmacokinetics
  • Absorption: Administered IV or IM 
  • Distribution: Widely distributed in the body, including CSF
  • Metabolism: Minimal metabolism
  • Excretion: Primarily excreted unchanged in urine, requires renal dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment. (Option D) 

Mechanism of Action

Aztreonam ⟶ Binds to Penicillin-Binding Proteins (PBPs) ⟶ Inhibits Peptidoglycan Cross-linking ⟶ Disruption of Bacterial Cell Wall Synthesis ⟶ Cell Lysis ⟶ Bacterial Death

 

Resistant to beta-lactamases, but susceptible to metallo-beta-lactamases and extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs).

Uses

Treatment of Gram-negative bacterial infections (e.g. Salmonella typhi, Pseudomonas), not effective against Gram-positive bacteria or Anaerobes. (Option A)

  • Urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Lower respiratory tract infections
  • Septicemia
  • Skin and skin structure infections
  • Intra-abdominal infections
  • Gynecological infections

It is particularly useful for patients allergic to penicillins or cephalosporins.

Side Effects

Common:

  • Rash
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
 

Serious:

  • Hypersensitivity reactions (anaphylaxis)
  • Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhoea
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia

Special Points
  • It can be used in patients with penicillin allergy due to low cross-reactivity, except for Ceftazidime. (Option C)
  • Often combined with beta-lactamase inhibitors (Avibactam) to expand the spectrum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient residing in Delhi presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, hypotension, and altered mental status. Blood cultures are positive for a gram-negative bacillus. The patient is diagnosed with sepsis, and subsequent laboratory testing reveals that the causative organism produces New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM-1). Given this information, which of the following is the best treatment choice?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Ceftazidime-avibactam

Explanation:

Metallobactamase-producing bacteria produce an enzyme called metallobactamase, which can break down and make certain antibiotics ineffective.

These bacteria can cause severe infections and are often resistant to multiple antibiotics, making them challenging to treat.

Ceftazidime-avibactam is a combination of a third-generation cephalosporin and a non-beta-lactam beta-lactamase inhibitor. Avibactam can inhibit NDM-1, making this combination effective against NDM-1-producing organisms.

 

Meropenem (Option A) is a broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic. However, it is generally ineffective against organisms producing NDM-1, as these bacteria can hydrolyse carbapenems and render them useless.

Piperacillin-tazobactam (Option B) is a combination of a broad-spectrum penicillin and a beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is ineffective against organisms producing NDM-1, as NDM-1 can hydrolyse a wide range of beta-lactams, including those protected by beta-lactamase inhibitors.

Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Option D) combines a penicillin antibiotic and a beta-lactamase inhibitor. NDM-1 can also hydrolyse this combination.

questions.text: A patient initially admitted to the intensive care unit with respiratory failure was escalated to invasive ventilation. Few days later, he developed a fever along with basal crackles and patchy consolidation can be seen in chest X-ray. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Imipenem-cilastatin

Explanation:

The above clinical vignette suggests ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and carbapenems like imipenem combined with cilastatin are the most likely drug of choice.

Carbapenems:

  • Imipenem (with cilastatin)
  • Meropenem
  • Faropenem
  • Doripenem
  • Ertapenem
  • Uses of carbapenems:
    • Used in nosocomial infections.
    • DOC in
      • Acinetobacter baumannii (Ventilator-associated pneumonia)(most common cause of VAP nowadays)
      • Klebsiella
      • Burkholderia
      • Serratia
      • Proteus
      • Pseudomonas

questions.text: A patient who initially presented with symptoms of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is found to be methicillin-resistant. The report also said vancomycin would also be ineffective in this organism. Which of the following cephalosporins can most likely be used effectively in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Ceftaroline fosamil

Explanation:

Fifth-generation cephalosporins like ceftaroline fosamil and ceftobiprole medocaril are found to be effective against MRSA.

Uses of cephalosporins:

First generation
  • ENT, upper respiratory & cutaneous infections
  • Cephazolin is the DOC for surgical site infection prophylaxis 

Second generation
  • Mixed aerobic-anaerobic infections (Only cephalosporin class effective against anaerobes)
 

Third generation
  • Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime: empirical therapy for meningitis
  • Ceftazidime: Pseudomonas meningitis
  • STI : Gonorrhea, chancroid, syphilis
  • Enteric fever
  • Patients with neutropenia

Fourth generation
  • Nosocomial infections (intensive care borne)
 

Fifth generation
  • Penicillin resistant community acquired and hospital acquired pneumonia by S.pneumoniae
  • Penicillinase producing S.aureus infections
  • MRSA

 

Cephalosporin effective against pseudomonas:
All P containing cephalosporins: Cefpirome Cefepime, Cefoperazone, and Ceftazidime (most effective)

questions.text: Which of the following is a 4th generation cephalosporin?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Cefpirome

Explanation:

Cefpirome is a 4th generation cephalosporin.

Cephalosporins are a group of antibiotics derived from cephalosporin-C, which is obtained from the fungus Cephalosporium. They are chemically related to penicillins.

Classification of cephalosporins:

They are classified into 5 generations.

Ceftibuten

questions.text: A patient who was admitted with suspected osteomyelitis is found to be caused by Staphylococcus aureus that shows resistance to methicillin. Which of the following is least likely to be the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chloramphenicol

Explanation:

The patient has osteomyelitis caused by MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), which requires agents active against MRSA. While chloramphenicol has a broad spectrum and can penetrate tissues well, it is not a preferred or reliable agent for MRSA, especially in serious infections like osteomyelitis. It is bacteriostatic, has variable activity against MRSA, and carries the risk of serious adverse effects such as aplastic anemia and bone marrow suppression.

Drugs commonly used for MRSA infections:

  1. Vancomycin (Option D)
  2. Linezolid (Option C)
  3. Teicoplanin (Option A)
  4. Tedizolid
  5. Daptomycin
  6. Quinupristin/Dalfopristin
  7. Mupirocin

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding penicillinase-resistant penicillins except?

choices.text: Dicloxacillin falls in this group of drugs.
Methicillin is preferred in patients with renal disease.
Not resistant to penicillinase of gram-negative bacteria.
Concomitant use of contraceptive pills is contraindicated with nafcillin.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Methicillin is preferred in patients with renal disease.

Explanation:

The increasing incidence of hematuria, albuminuria and interstitial nephritis as adverse effects of being on methicillin is one of the major reasons why the drug is no longer used widely.

This group of drugs protects the beta-lactam ring of the drug from staphylococcal penicillinase. Their only indication is to use them in penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus, which is not methicillin-resistant.

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins

Side effects

Cloxacillin (oral)

Coagulation defect/bleeding

Oxacillin (oral)

Hepatotoxicity

Nafcillin (IV)

Neutropenia

Dicloxacillin (oral) (Option A)

Hepatotoxicity

 

 This group of drugs is not resistant to penicillinase produced by Gram-negative bacteria and hence cannot be used in such cases. (Option C)

Nafcillin is a known inducer of cytochrome P450 enzymes which render drugs like oral contraceptive pills ineffective and hence concomitant use of these drugs is contraindicated. (Option D)

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect about extended spectrum penicillins except?

choices.text: Ampicillin is one of the preferred drugs of choice in typhoid fever.
The biliary concentration of ampicillin is low and hence not used in cholecystitis.
Piperacillin is more potent than carbenicillin in pseudomonas infections.
Carbenicillin is the preferred drug in this group in heart failure patients.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Piperacillin is more potent than carbenicillin in pseudomonas infections.

Explanation:

Piperacillin is almost 8 times more potent than carbenicillin in treating Pseudomonas infections

Extended-spectrum penicillins act against a variety of Gram-negative bacteria in addition to its basic nature of acting against Gram-positive bacteria. They include:

  • Aminopenicillins:
    • Ampicillin.
    • Bacampicillin.
    • Amoxicillin.
  • Carboxypenicillins:
    • Carbenicillin.
    • Ticarcillin.
  • Ureidopenicillins:
    • Piperacillin.
    • Mezlocillin.

 

Ampicillin is now not used in typhoid fever because of the emergence of resistance. (Option A)

Ampicillin is partly excreted in bile and also reabsorbed to enter the entero-hepatic circulation. Hence it can be used in cholecystitis because it presents in high concentrations in bile. (Option B)

Carbenicillin when used in its salt format will retain water and hence subjectively not preferred in patients with heart or renal failure. (Option D)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male recently began treatment for painless lesions in his palms and soles and presented to the emergency department with fever, chills, and myalgias. These symptoms developed a few hours after receiving his first dose of benzathine penicillin G. On examination, he appears flushed (image) with tachycardia and hypotension. Based on the findings, match the most likely diagnosis and management of this condition.




	
		
			
			1. Anaphylactic reaction
			
			
			A. Continue medication and start antipyretics
			
		
		
			
			2. Serum Sickness
			
			
			B. Administer epinephrine
			
		
		
			
			3. Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction
			
			
			C. Discontinue and switch to alternate medication
			
		
		
			
			4. Steven-Johnson syndrome
			
			
			D. Discontinue medication and admit to ICU
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 3 and A

Explanation:

This patient is experiencing a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, a typical response to antibiotic treatment for syphilis, characterised by fever, chills, myalgias and worsening of syphilitic rash, which usually resolves within 24 hours without discontinuing penicillin therapy. Supportive treatment includes antipyretics and corticosteroids.

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:

  • Host reaction is due to the release of spirochetal proteins (hypersensitivity).
  • Common in patients treated for secondary syphilis, leptospirosis, and Lyme disease.
  • Symptoms:
    • Chills, fever, headache, and myalgias occur several hours after the first dose.
    • It is worsening of syphilitic rash (image) and lymphadenopathy.
  • Management:
    • Self-limited: resolves within 24 hours.
    • Supportive care: Antipyretics, hydration and corticosteroids.
    • Continue penicillin therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the hospital with headaches, difficulty coordinating his movements, and memory loss over the past six months. On physical examination, his pupils are irregular and do not constrict to light but constrict during accommodation. He had a history of painless genital ulcer, which was resolved on its own a few years ago. What is the drug of choice used for this condition in this patient?

choices.text: A single dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G
Once weekly dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G
Once weekly dose of 24 million IU penicillin G
Continues dose of 24 million IU aqueous penicillin G

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Continues dose of 24 million IU aqueous penicillin G

Explanation:

This patient's history of untreated painless genital ulcer (chancre) presenting with progressive neurological symptoms along with examination revealing Argyll Robertson pupils suggest neurosyphilis as the most likely diagnosis, which should be treated with a continuous intravenous infusion of Continues dose of 24 million IU aqueous penicillin G

Syphilis:

  • Sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • Classification:

Stages of Syphilis

Treatment

Primary syphilis

Chancre (painless genital ulcer)

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU (Option A)

Secondary syphilis

Spread in blood: Rash involving palms and soles, uveitis

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Early latent syphilis

Dormant for < 1 year

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Late latent syphilis

Dormant for > 1 year

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option B)

Tertiary syphilis

Activation after one year and damages the organs (gummas)

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option C)

Damage to heart: Cardiovascular syphilis (aortic aneurysm, arteritis)

Damage to the brain: Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis, ataxia, dementia, Argyl Robertson pupils)

Continues IV Aqueous Penicillin G 18-24 IU for 10-14 days. (Option D)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding penicillins is true?


	Acid-stable penicillins are destroyed by gastric acid and must be administered parenterally.
	Penicillin G is an acid-stable penicillin that should be given in high doses if administered orally.
	Acid-stable penicillins are avoided with food and antacids.
	Acid labile penicillins include amoxicillin, ampicillin and oxacillin.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 3 only

Explanation:

Acid Labile Penicillin

Acid Stable Penicillin
  • Penicillin G is degraded in the stomach by HCl (Statement 2)
  • Route:
    • Parenteral
    • If oral necessary: given in high doses
  • Resistant to gastric HCl (Statement 1)
  • Route: Oral
  • Drugs: Mnemonic: VODCAA
    • Penicillin V (No effect on meningococcus)
    • Oxacillin
    • Dicloxacillin, Flucloxacillin
    • Cloxacillin
    • Ampicillin
    • Amoxicillin (Statement 4)
  • Avoid food and antacids except for amoxicillin (Statement 3)
  • Given 30 mins before food or >2 hrs after food

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with a sore throat and fever for three days. Previous medical history includes breathing issues and rashes caused by an unknown medicine used to treat syphilis one year ago. A throat swab confirms the streptococcal infection. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Erythromycin

Explanation:

This patient with a history of anaphylaxis (trouble breathing and rash) after starting medication to treat sore throat suggests penicillin hypersensitivity reaction and should be prescribed erythromycin due to the risk of cross-reactivity with similar drugs like amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, and penicillin V.

Penicillin Hypersensitivity:

  • Incidence: 4-5%
  • This is due to the product breakdown called “major determinant” or the penicilloyl moiety.
  • It may occur at any dose and in the absence of a previous exposure.
  • Allergic testing: Intradermal 6-aminopenicillins acid (benzylpenicilloyl polylysine).
  • Types:
    • Type 1 (immediate): Sudden death due to anaphylaxis (Purpuric eruption, hypotension, bronchoconstriction and GI symptoms).
    • Type 2: Hemolytic anaemia (Detected through Coombs test), neutropenia.
    • Type 3: Serum sickness (presents after one week and persists after discontinuation).
    • Type 4 (Delayed type): Steven-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis.
  • Treatment:
    • Discontinue the medication and avoid similar classes of antibiotics (avoid all beta-lactams but monobactam is safe as it has a different structure that lacks the characteristic beta-lactam ring configuration. This structural difference significantly reduces the risk of cross-reactivity with other beta-lactam antibiotics. (Options A, B and D ruled out).
    • DOC: Macrolides (Erythromycin, Azithromycin).
    • Alternate: Clindamycin
    • Desensitisation in ICU setting: In patients who must receive the drug

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student arrives at the emergency room complaining of photophobia, high fever and severe headache. A physical examination reveals pain when extending the legs and stiffness on neck flexion. Following a lumbar puncture, the cerebrospinal fluid was cloudy, with high protein, low glucose and raised white blood cell count. What is the most appropriate treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)Intravenous Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

The young student has classical symptoms of bacterial meningitis (severe headache, high fever, photophobia, and positive Kernig's sign), and CSF findings of bacterial meningitis suggest meningococcal meningitis as the most likely diagnosis. This should be treated with ceftriaxone, a broad-spectrum third-generation cephalosporin with good CSF penetration.

Meningococcal Meningitis

Causative organism
  • Neisseria meningitidis

Treatment
  • DOC: IV Ceftriaxone (Third generation cephalosporin)

Prophylaxis
  • Adult: Ciprofloxacin (earlier Rifampicin)
    • Prevents nasal colonisation
  • Children and Pregnant women:
    • Ceftriaxone injection (as Ciprofloxacin ( FQ) causes cartilage damage in children and fetus).

 

 

Intravenous acyclovir (Option A) is recommended for VZV-associated and HSV meningitis, showing normal glucose, increased protein, and lymphocytic pleocytosis on CSF examination.

 

Intravenous vancomycin (Option B) is advised for resistant cases of healthcare-associated meningitis and ventriculitis but not as a first-line treatment for bacterial meningitis.

 

Intravenous amphotericin B (Option D) plus flucytosine is used for cryptococcal meningitis in HIV patients, showing elevated opening pressure, increased protein, low glucose, and slight lymphocytic predominance on CSF examination.

questions.text: Penicillin is helpful for the treatment of all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) MRSA pneumonia

Explanation:

Vancomycin, a glycopeptide antibiotic, is the drug of choice for Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection.

Penicillins

Classification
  • Natural Penicillins
    • Penicillin G/Benzylpenicillin/Crystalline penicillin
      • First penicillin
      • Parenteral route only
      • Allergic potential
      • Narrow spectrum
      • Resistance exhibited by beta-lactamase enzyme-producing organisms
      •  
    • Penicillin V: Enteral route
  • Penicillinase resistant penicillin
    • Methicillin, cloxacillin, nafcillin, oxacillin, and dicloxacillin
  • Aminopenicillins: Ampicillin, amoxicillin.
  • Anti-pseudomonal penicillins: Piperacillin, ticarcillin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Poor CNS penetration (except Penicillin G and nafcillin)
  • Poor eye penetration
  • Poor prostate penetration

Uses (SMART Player GAYLE)
  • S: Syphilis: DOC for neurosyphilis (Option B ruled out)
  • M: Meningococcal meningitis
  • A: Actinomycosis
  • R: Rat bite fever: Streptobacillus, Spirillosis
  • T: Tetanus
  • Player: Pasteurella multocida
  • G: Gas gangrene (Myonecrosis): Clostridium perfringens
  • A: Anthrax
  • Y: Yaws
  • L: Leptospirosis (Option D ruled out)
  • E: Every species: Streptococcus, Staphylococcus if sensitive (Option A ruled out)

 

 

 Treatment of syphilis:


1° syphilis/ 2° syphilis/ Early latent : Benzathine penicillin single depot injection i/m 2.4 million IU


LATE latent: Benzathine penicillin G- three doses of 2.4 million units IM at one-week intervals.


Neuro syphilis: Aqueous Penicillin G continuous infusion i/v
